awd_titl_txt: PFI-TT: Advancing Nanocellulose-Enabled Bio-Nanofertilizers for Agriculture
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impacts and commercial potentials of this Partnerships for Innovation - Technology Translation (PFI-TT) project will significantly reduce the nitrogen fertilizer usage, thus reducing the total greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions.  Overuse of nitrogen fertilizers leads to nutrient losses that contribute to climatic change that in turn negatively affects agricultural productivity and environmental health. This project creates a new nanofertilizer from underutilized biomass feedstocks and wastewater nutrient recovery.  Furthermore, this project trains future leaders in agricultural entrepreneurship and innovation management.

The proposed project advances a simple approach using nitric acid-sodium nitrite mixtures (both are key ingredients for N-fertilizer synthesis) that can extract nanocellulose directly from untreated non-woody plants (e.g. agricultural residues) with significant reduction of chemical, water and energy needs. This nitro-oxidation process (NOP) approach combines the steps of pulping and cellulose oxidation. In addition, the spent liquor in the process can be readily converted into plant fertilizer. Nanocellulose has been shown to be an effective scaffolding material to host a multitude of organic and inorganic nanoparticles and to create low-cost and environmentally friendly nanocomposite. The proposed activities will (1) demonstrate and evaluate the scale-up of NOP operation, involving process optimization, safety procedure development, efficient conversion of spent liquor and understanding of the structure-functionality-process relationships from various  non-woody biomass feedstocks, and (2) synthesize a new kind of nanocellulose-enabled bio-nanofertilizer, including ammonium-nanocellulose, ZnO nanoparticle-nanocellulose, and CuO nanoparticle-anchored nanocellulose composites. The proposed research will provide new knowledge for creating effective nanofertilizers and for overcoming technical hurdles to upcycle two major waste streams i.e., underutilized biomass, and excess N-nutrients in wastewater.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR THE STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK

por.por_cntn:
Summary

 

This PFI-TT project aimed to demonstrate a new kind of nanocellulose-enabled bio-nanofertilizer for agricultural applications. The foundational technologies in this project were two: (1) the nitro-oxidation process (NOP) that can extract nanocellulose from diverse lignocellulosic biomass feedstocks with zero waste, and (2) synthesis of the extracted nanocellulose which can be used for soil health restoration. The outcomes of this project are three. (1) Successful scale-up demonstration of the NOP approach to prepare nanocellulose from two woody and non-woody model plant feedstocks (soft wood and jute). (2) Performance evaluation of nanocellulose-derived bio-nanofertilizers for the growth study of a model crop (soybean). (3) Completion of extensive end-user and stakeholder interviews regarding market needs and technology validation through regional and national I-Corps trainings. Furthermore, the project enabled the PI to execute a licensing agreement to transfer the technologies to a local startup, paving a path for commercialization.

 

Scientific Merit

 

The NOP approach combines pulping and cellulose oxidation processes to extract nanocellulose and biofertilizer with a significant reduction of chemical, water and energy consumption (at lab scale, this method consumes 80% lower amounts of chemicals, 50% lower water and 80% lower electrical energy than conventional methods).The demonstrated NOP technology was validated as a low-cost, zero-waste manufacturing process that can produce high value fertilizer supplements and biogels to advance the nexus of food-energy-water systems. Specifically, nanocellulose-enabled bioproducts can be prepared from underutilized biomass feedstocks and wastewater promoting nutrient recovery to significantly reduce N-fertilizer usage and total GHG emissions, where nanocellulose-derived bio-nanofertilizers enable the development of new soilless crop growth media.  Based on this project, the PI/Co-PI have also made over 3 scientific presentations and delivered 5 invited talks in national and international meetings.

 

Broader Impacts

 

The broader impacts of this project included the regional and national I-Corps trainings for PI, 1 post-doc and 2 PhD students, where the activities have taught them how to build the foundation commercialization plan of the startup, convey customer discovery, end-user interviews and develop business plans. Additionally, 5 undergraduate students were offered the opportunities to conduct applied research in development of sustainable nanocellulose-enabled bio-nanofertilizer for agricultural applications based on end-user survey. Furthermore, 5 high school students were mentored in summer research in 2022, where 2 have won regional semifinalist status in Regeneron STS Scholars competitions. While learning about the concepts of enhanced food-water nexus, these high school students have carried out a broad range of innovative research projects addressing access to food security and safe drinking water as urgent issues of global sustainability. Notably, the widespread use of conventional fertilizers in agriculture nationwide is not currently sustainable for a variety of reasons including the availability of inventories, significant product cost increases, high delivery inefficiency, significant consumption of water and energy and high possibilities for negative environmental impact (e.g., high greenhouse gas emissions and nitrogen/phosphorus pollution of water bodies).

 


Last Modified: 05/19/2024
Modified by: Benjamin S Hsiao

Image
  • An illustration of a nitrogen life cycle using nitro-oxidized cellulose nanofibers (NOCNF) as an ammonium adsorbent and plant fertilizer. NOCNF is prepared from agricultural residue, upcycled to be used as an adsorbent nanomaterial, and terminates as a fertilizer at the end of its life cycle.
    Benjamin Hsiao
    Copyrighted
    Benjamin S Hsiao
    Nanocellulose technology to enhance the nexus of food and water
